11 OF BALTIMORE
DEFEATS FROSH
Jay Freshmen Lose Close Battle by Score of 6 to 0
MENDOHLSON STARS
Single Score Made in Second
Quarter
The University of Baltimore
freshman football team fought its
way to a victory over the Johns
Hopkins freshmen by a score of
6-0. The game, which was played
at the Homewood field, was witnessed by only a handful of people.
Hopkins started the game with
the second team. The first quarter
Was mainly exchanges of kicks,
with the University of Baltimore
gradually gaining, until at the end
of the period they had the ball in
the Blue territory.
Hopkins' first team went in.
University of Baltimore Scores

At the beginning of the second
quarter, after several runs the University of Baltimore carried the ball
over for a touchdown. The try for
point failed and the score stood at
6-0, University of Baltimore. Hopkins kicked off. After one or two
plays Cockey of Hopkins covered
a fumble on the University of Baltimore's 40-yard line. It looked like
a chance to score, but the Jay
freshmen lost the ball on downs,
failing to make yardage by a mere
foot. Neither team could gain and
after three exchanges of kicks the
half ended.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 22, 1929

Vol. XXXIV, No. 16

FROSH "Y" CABINET
OFFICERS ELECTED
Last Tuesday, Nov. 19, the
second freshman Y. M. C. A.
dinner was held, this time for
the purpose of electing officers
of the freshman cabinet.
About forty men attended
the meeting.
After dinner, nominations
were reopened. The additional
nominations were as follows:
President, Williams; vicepresident, Frey and Wollenberg; secretary, Reid, Packard, Hughes and Lehman;
treasurer, Wollenberg, Reid
and Packard.
The results of the election
were as follows: Mattingly,
president; Gilbert, vice-president; Hughes, secretary, and
Cockey, treasurer.

HOPKINS SUPPORTERS REPELLED BY
POLICE OF ENEMY STRONGHOLD
Last Friday night after the
parade, it might have been observed
that a group of determined-looking
young gentlemen were going around
from frat house to f. h. and, judging by all appearances, were plotting some sort of mysterious—shall
we say diabolical ?—affair, utterly
baffling to all those who tried to
investigate.
About twelve o'clock, a number
of Hopkins men, armed with stout
hearts and loaded fire extinguishers,
started to patrol the campus. VVere
they crazy, or did some vague, unknown peril really threaten Hopkins? At any rate, the self-appointed protectors of Homewood
halted several of the cars driving
around the "sugar bowl" and from
rumors that have leaked out about
this affair we hear that the occupants were closely scrutinized. After a half an hour of this new outdoor sport, two cars were seen to
drive repeatedly around the "birthday cake." After five minutes,
agonizing with suspense, the aforesaid vehicles of transportation
pulled up to the curb, and, for some
unknown reason, the occupants
burst into cheers, enthusiastically
shouting the name of another college. But their visit was cut short
by an unexpected act of extreme
inhospitality, for the worthies with
loaded fire extinguishers dashed
speedily down from the Quad and
proceeded to project several streams
of mustard water at the visitors.
Please do not ask why, for this
matter has baffled the detectives of
one and a half cities.
'Twas far in the mysterious wee
small hours—to be exact it was
3 A. M. Saturday—when an automobile—or, to speak with more
accuracy, a Chevrolet touring car—
loaded with no less than nine of our

students departed from their Alma
Mater, and soon the friendly lights
of Baltimore Town were left behind. After getting lost twice or
possibly thrice, our nocturnal adventurers finally saw another set of
lights loom before their weary eyes.
The next few minutes revealed that
they were—of all places—in Annapolis.
After driving around at random
for a while these unofficial representatives to the state capital rode
slowly past the forbidding estates
and frowning walls of some institution which—ah! another mystery
of that night—seemed to be
guarded. At any rate, it soon became all too evident that the village
gendarmerie were on the scene, for
our nine worthies found themselves
being courteously and minutely directed to the local Bastille. In fact,
the escort was so considerate as to
go so far as, to volunteer to conduct
them personally to their goal—or
was it to be gaol?
The police sergeant, after entertaining the Hopkins men who were
his guests and detaining them for
the better part of an hour, finally
allowed them to breath again the
free air of the great outdoors. And
now again they sallied forth to the
street in front of the institution
mentioned above, where they proceeded to indulge in a series of
Hopkins cheers, which evidently
cruelly roused the slumberers
within from the arms of sweet
Morpheus.
By 8.371/2 A. M. they had returned to the friendly greensward
of Homewood, exactly 171/2 minutes late for 8.30 classes, which
was too bad, but it couldn't, of
course, be helped under the circumstances. After all, it isn't every

COTILLION BOARD
DANCE TOMORROW
There will be no tea dance
tomorrow afternoon, but the
regular Saturday night dance
from 9 to 12 P. M. will be
held by the Cotillion Board.
Bob Iula and his orchestra
will furnish the music. The
regular price of $1 stag or
couple will be charged. A
handsome door prize will be
given to the lucky couple.
The price of tickets of the
1929 Hullabaloo dance, which
will be held at the Southern,
will be $2 per couple and
$1.50 stag, not $1 as announced in the last NEWSLETTER.

EDITORIALS

,

O

ANOTHER "JAY"
ITH the appearance of the Aviation number of the fay. our
• own reviewer produced an unnecessarily severe criticism of the
latest product of our contemporary. Though charges of lack of
originality are in large measure true, the difficulties of writing original
humor is by no means slight. The staff of the fay, in so far as we are
able to observe is doing its best to make its book appealing to the
student body and if it is failing, criticism must be sincerely constructive
and not merely violently antagonistic. At times the NEWS-LETTER and
the Jay have provided amusement for the campus by engaging in a
bitter war of words. At the present such unfriendly feeling has
vanished and we are not desirous of reviving it. Our criticisms are
meant to be helpful and we shall accept with good grace any criticism
directed at us when it comes without malice.
Last year the Jay was supposed to have changed its policy to include
material of a more serious nature in its columns. This policy has not
been fuly utilized. We are of the opinion that improvement would
result if the Jay were to exclude the numerous would-be humorous
stories and skits which clutter its pages. It is so very difficult to make
such efforts really humorous, that it were far better to avoid them rather
than publish numbers that are inferior. The editor of the Jay is confronted with no small task in fulfilling the purposes of his magazine
faithfully.
One thing which struck our attention rather forcibly in the last
issue was the excellent grade of advertising which grace its columns.
The business staff is to be congratulated on its enterprise.

The nourishment of the dormitory residents is one of the primary
considerations and worries. ; Far
different is the rate of metabolism
of this group of people from others.
The abnormal appetite developed by
these individuals due to their many
and varied antics, must, perforce, be
satisfied by an increased number of
food calories. To meet this catastrophic exigence the expedient of a

that Far Eastern republic, the

The most outstanding fact about
Russia today, said Mr. Porter, is
that she is becoming more and more
a part of Asia. It is one of the
results of the World War that Russia has begun "to face the rising
sun in more ways than one."

Jay Freshmen Lose Close Battle by Score of 6 to 0
MENDOHLSON STARS
Single Score Made in Second

The University of Baltimore
freshman football team fought its
way to a victory over the Johns
Hopkins freshmen by a score of
6-0. The game, which was played
at the Homewood field, was witnessed by only a handful of people.
Hopkins started the game with
the second team. The first quarter
Was mainly exchanges of kicks,
with the University of Baltimore
gradually gaining, until at the end
of the period they had the ball in
the Blue territory.
Hopkins' first team went in.
University of Baltimore Scores

At the beginning of the second
quarter, after several runs the University of Baltimore carried the ball
over for a touchdown. The try for
point failed and the score stood at
6-0, University of Baltimore. Hopkins kicked off. After one or two
plays Cockey of Hopkins covered
a fumble on the University of Baltimore's 40-yard line. It looked like
a chance to score, but the Jay
freshmen lost the ball on downs,
failing to make yardage by a mere
foot. Neither team could gain and
after three exchanges of kicks the
half ended.

FROSH "Y" CABINET
OFFICERS ELECTED
Last Tuesday, Nov. 19, the
second freshman Y. M. C. A.
dinner was held, this time for
the purpose of electing officers
of the freshman cabinet.
About forty men attended
the meeting.
After dinner, nominations
were reopened. The additional
nominations were as follows:
President, Williams; vicepresident, Frey and Wollenberg; secretary, Reid, Packard, Hughes and Lehman;
treasurer, Wollenberg, Reid
and Packard.
The results of the election
were as follows: Mattingly,
president; Gilbert, vice-president; Hughes, secretary, and
Cockey, treasurer.

Last Friday night after the
parade, it might have been observed
that a group of determined-looking
young gentlemen were going around
from frat house to f. h. and, judging by all appearances, were plotting some sort of mysterious—shall
we say diabolical ?—affair, utterly
baffling to all those who tried to
investigate.
About twelve o'clock, a number
of Hopkins men, armed with stout
hearts and loaded fire extinguishers,
started to patrol the campus. VVere
they crazy, or did some vague, unknown peril really threaten Hopkins? At any rate, the self-appointed protectors of Homewood
halted several of the cars driving
around the "sugar bowl" and from
rumors that have leaked out about
this affair we hear that the occupants were closely scrutinized. After a half an hour of this new outdoor sport, two cars were seen to
drive repeatedly around the "birthday cake." After five minutes,
agonizing with suspense, the aforesaid vehicles of transportation
pulled up to the curb, and, for some
unknown reason, the occupants
burst into cheers, enthusiastically
shouting the name of another college. But their visit was cut short
by an unexpected act of extreme
inhospitality, for the worthies with
loaded fire extinguishers dashed
speedily down from the Quad and
proceeded to project several streams
of mustard water at the visitors.
Please do not ask why, for this
matter has baffled the detectives of
one and a half cities.
'Twas far in the mysterious wee
small hours—to be exact it was
3 A. M. Saturday—when an automobile—or, to speak with more
accuracy, a Chevrolet touring car—
loaded with no less than nine of our

students departed from their Alma
Mater, and soon the friendly lights
of Baltimore Town were left behind. After getting lost twice or
possibly thrice, our nocturnal adventurers finally saw another set of
lights loom before their weary eyes.
The next few minutes revealed that
they were—of all places—in Annapolis.
After driving around at random
for a while these unofficial representatives to the state capital rode
slowly past the forbidding estates
and frowning walls of some institution which—ah! another mystery
of that night—seemed to be
guarded. At any rate, it soon became all too evident that the village
gendarmerie were on the scene, for
our nine worthies found themselves
being courteously and minutely directed to the local Bastille. In fact,
the escort was so considerate as to
go so far as, to volunteer to conduct
them personally to their goal—or
was it to be gaol?
The police sergeant, after entertaining the Hopkins men who were
his guests and detaining them for
the better part of an hour, finally
allowed them to breath again the
free air of the great outdoors. And
now again they sallied forth to the
street in front of the institution
mentioned above, where they proceeded to indulge in a series of
Hopkins cheers, which evidently
cruelly roused the slumberers
within from the arms of sweet
Morpheus.
By 8.371/2 A. M. they had returned to the friendly greensward
of Homewood, exactly 171/2 minutes late for 8.30 classes, which
was too bad, but it couldn't, of
course, be helped under the circumstances. After all, it isn't every

EDITORIALS

,

O

ANOTHER "JAY"
ITH the appearance of the Aviation number of the fay. our
• own reviewer produced an unnecessarily severe criticism of the
latest product of our contemporary. Though charges of lack of
originality are in large measure true, the difficulties of writing original
humor is by no means slight. The staff of the fay, in so far as we are
able to observe is doing its best to make its book appealing to the
student body and if it is failing, criticism must be sincerely constructive
and not merely violently antagonistic. At times the NEWS-LETTER and
the Jay have provided amusement for the campus by engaging in a
bitter war of words. At the present such unfriendly feeling has
vanished and we are not desirous of reviving it. Our criticisms are
meant to be helpful and we shall accept with good grace any criticism
directed at us when it comes without malice.
Last year the Jay was supposed to have changed its policy to include
material of a more serious nature in its columns. This policy has not
been fuly utilized. We are of the opinion that improvement would
result if the Jay were to exclude the numerous would-be humorous
stories and skits which clutter its pages. It is so very difficult to make
such efforts really humorous, that it were far better to avoid them rather
than publish numbers that are inferior. The editor of the Jay is confronted with no small task in fulfilling the purposes of his magazine
faithfully.
One thing which struck our attention rather forcibly in the last
issue was the excellent grade of advertising which grace its columns.
The business staff is to be congratulated on its enterprise.

ALBRIGHT LECTURE
(Continued from page 4, Col. 3)
were found in this town whose
principal industry was wool. Each
plant had two massive stone basins
of about one-half a ton apiece in
which the cloth was steeped. Numerous large hollowed-out stones belonging to pipe lines which were
used to convey water to the plants
were found.
The inhabitants of • these cities
showed an astounding amount of
energy in hewing these stone basins
and pipe lines. This energy is also
attested by the fact that almost
every peasant house in town was
supported by four massive stone
pillars which were dragged from
the quarry up a hill to the town.
Many cosmetic palettes of carved
stone were found in the stratum belonging to the pre-exile Jews.
These were used for powdering the
mineral substances used in painting
women's faces.
In the upper strata belonging to
the Israelites quantities of iron
tools and weapons,' increasing in
abundance as time went on, were
found. Iron, according to the lecturer, was introduced shortly after
the Israelite conquest of Canaan.
Due to the monopoly. of iron production by the Hittite of Asia
Minor, the Canaanites Were unable
to employ this metal to any extent.
At the time of the conquest of
Canaan, the Hitite Empire was
overthrown by a barbarian invasion. The leaders of the invasion,
the PhiJisitines, then monopolized
the iron in Palestine for several
generations. This monopoly was
broken by King Saul as described in
the Bible.

These antics exemplified by the
dormitory contingent are not to be
scoffed at by the more sober-minded
among us. The "grad" students
have initiated a series of soccer
tilts before the stately portals of
Gilman on the quadrangle at thv
same time. We look toward these
conglomerative sport systems in
developing worthy varsity material
or at least efficient water-carrier.
Within the learned walls of the
Dorm some few upper - classmen
who wrestle with the mysteries of
physiographical wonder s, make
preparations for trips where the
geological wonders, shrouded in
myriads of technical revelations,
will be unfolded to them. Breeches
and high boots predominate, but
there are very essential little nonentities not to be excluded. A
geology hammer is of invaluable
assistance in cracking nuts on a
trip. Then, too, a pipe is quite indispensable. The outfit is most
satisfactorily completed by a pocket
addition. Those well versed in the
past history of former geological
ventures think it is extremely imperative to partake of a round of
golf, of the African variety. Already these enthusiasts utilize a part
of the week-end in acquiring a
generous portion of skill and
adeptness in the delicate art.
The nourishment of the dormitory residents is one of the primary
considerations and worries. ; Far
different is the rate of metabolism
of this group of people from others.
The abnormal appetite developed by
these individuals due to their many
and varied antics, must, perforce, be
satisfied by an increased number of
food calories. To meet this catastrophic exigence the expedient of a
fourth meal is commonly and nightly practiced at the Dorm. One of
the more capable roomers takes it
upon himself to distribute the edibles at a minimum cost. We would
strenuously advise the nightly call,
"Ice cold sandwiches and good
milk" to be c.hanged entirely, for we
presume it to mean "Ice cold milk
and good sandwiches."

that Far Eastern republic, the
speaker asserted that there is in
reality no unified control in China.
Ever since the Central Government
succeeded in overthrowing the Manchu dynasty in 1911, it has itself
been constantly threatened by revolutions. At the present, for instance, we have the odd spectacle
of communists and conservatives
co-operating, each party hoping
that if it succeeds in ousting the
Central Government, it will gain its
own ends at the expense of the
other. "At least, that was true yesterday," Mr. Porter hastened to
add;"what is true today, in view of
the rapid changes that occur, I do
not know."
The most outstanding fact about
Russia today, said Mr. Porter, is
that she is becoming more and more
a part of Asia. It is one of the
results of the World War that Russia has begun "to face the rising
sun in more ways than one."
The lively discussion which followed Mr. Porter's address, gave
evidence of the stimulating effect
which it had upon the large audience, which included several students from other institutions than
Johns Hopkins.

place.

To the Editor of the
NEWS-LETTER,
Dear Sir:
The manner in which sham intelligentsia jump at one another's
throats out here at Homewood is
quite amusing. Would-be satirists
snap their fangs at most anything
and everything in order to have
their childish sentiments appear in
writing and their fictitious ingeneous pen names in bold type. So
far as yet constructive criticism on
the part of able critics has not come
into its own. Let us hope that the
day will come when such a situation
will hold sway.

It seems to me that Hopkins
would be a far better place for all,
if such learned cynics as those who
have been "ripping everything from
the R. 0. T. C. to the Y. M. C. A.
would humble their glorious selves
and lend their valuable talents to
the various extra curriculum activities. There is no sense beating
around the bush. Everyone knows
that a small group carries on all
that is Hopkins in the way of activities. Were it not for them, wellestablished
activities
collegiate
would crumble into ruins and be
things of the past. The student
body (that is, the majority of it)
is an extremely disinterested one
as far as activities are concerned.
This accounts for the fact that
there is no college spirit here at
Hopkins. One might say that this
thing they call "college spirit" is
entirely undesirable. This is a matter of opinion, and mine is that it
sincerely expresses the glories of
youth and brings out the finest in
a man's life during those four last
sweet years before branching out
into the world of trials and tribulations.
Not only are such "rippings" as
the above mentioned prominent hut
the various groups proceed to rip
into each other. For instance take
the case of the controversy between
the Black and Blue Jay and the
NEWS-LETTER. In the past issue
of the Jay, the conductors of the
"Around the Campus" page delighted in a typographical error and
a poorly expressed passage of the
paper, and a staff candidate of the
NEWS-LETTER, in a review of the
magazine, referred to it as being
entirely composed of mere "high
school wit."
Such situations as these are not
uncommon. Why should we as loyal
students let them grow? Why
not do away with prejudice, forget
self glory and unite in a grand
effort to BOOST HOPKNS.
